top_comment.author: sprybug

comments.text:
+lazerhaze There's gotta be more options for you for a fast internet 
connection.  This is why we can't have monopolies.
comments.author: sprybug

comments.text:
+sprybug I use a lot of video conferencing tech. I am hard of hearing and 
am bilingual as I speak English and American Sign Language. (ASL) Also my 
mother is deaf and we use video conferencing to communicate to each other 
and to those who aren't hearing impaired. We are able to speak face to face 
to those with video conferencing devices or to an interpreter who then 
speaks to a hearing person called and who then interprets back the 
responses to us in our native language (ASL). I need a quality bandwidth 
connection with little lag to be able to effectively use video 
conferencing. Only cable companies provide the service at a price we can 
afford and at a level of lag free high bandwidth that I and other deaf 
people need to have access to to effectively communicate. Also not everyone 
has access to wireless 4G access. Much of the nation is not within 4G 
service areas.
comments.author: lazerhaze

comments.text:
+DrunkVegan There is that.  I know what I said can only be done by so many. 
 Even back in the day, I got rid of ComCast and then hooked up with a local

the middle of nowhere at that time.  Today I live in Portland and I have 
Clear Wireless (I know Verizon just bought them, but at least they're not 
Comcast).  The reason why I went with them is because they're cheaper.  As 
long as someone comes along with a cheaper option, I'll move to it.

top_comment.text:
The only reason why Sen. Charles Schumer receives the most campaign money 
from Time Warner Cable is because Schumer's ban on data caps in NY State 
actually saved Time Warner Cable's business in the long run, especially 
when TWC is available in NY AND Los Angeles, which are markets that Comcast 
purposely avoided and left, respectively, right before the latter company 
implemented its data caps and throttling policies.

Unless, of course, Charles Schumer is purposely letting Comcast buy TWC, so 
that Comcast gets called out for its data capping AND throttling 
shenanigans.

Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, should be outright embarrassed how its biggest 
company is the source of all what is wrong with American internet, to the 
point JAPAN calls Americans "LAGGERS".  In real life, I ran into a 
Philadelphia native in a Comcast market and sardonically told him, "Thanks 
for Comcast"; he responded back, "I am well-aware of Comcast's 
reputation"...to the point Philly continually gets dissed into 
"FAILadelphia", because of Comcast's data capping and throttling 
shenanigans.  Even Occupy Philly occupied Comcast HQ.

Oh, here's Comcast HQ's contact info:

Comcast Headquarters
1701 John F. Kennedy Boulevard
Philadelphia, Pennsylvania
215-286-1700

Whether Comcast likes it or not, once they buy TWC, the FCC is waiting to 
clamp down on Comcast's data caps and throttling policies.  Seriously, data 
caps AND throttling on residential internet in Silicon Valley!?  Even The 
Bronx, of all places, has better internet!  Even L.A., let alone NYC, hate 
data caps.

As for Michael Powell, even Howard Stern called him out, even before the 
prior became the NCTA President.﻿

and peace. Now before I get flamed, of course governments in practice fail

admits it's selfish and greedy, or the thing that claims to care about all 
people and keeping peace? The latter may be lying, but the former certainly 
isn't.

Of course, I myself don't know which I would prefer. Seems we have to fight 
both nowadays :/.

top_comment.text:
Answer me this: What does www.wolf-pac.com propose the amendment should be? 
The website does not state this and wolf pac isn't the only organization to 
propose an amendment for this issue.

To a conservative, this is very important, because some bills proposed by 
liberals  are only criticized because it's a detriment to it's cause, not 
that it's a bad cause. I happen to think an amendment is a bad idea, but I 
can't even assess this because I don't even know what you're trying to do!

I think the only reason this organization is bi-partisan is because they're 
proposing a blank bill and everyone is using their imagination about what 
it will be.﻿
top_comment.author: George Cataloni

comments.text:
> *Ahh, thank you. I could not find that when I looked, probably because 
I'm not a member.*
Neither am I, I found it on the site "the plan": 
http://www.wolf-pac.com/the_plan
comments.author: o_O

comments.text:
+o_O Ahh, thank you. I could not find that when I looked, probably because 
I'm not a member. Such a thing is too important to hide in the blog.

I'm glad it's worded as such to exclude not just corporations, but any 
individual or union.

I don't agree with the "corporations are not people" clause, though. It 
would give too much power to government to control the economy to a 
legislator's whim. All it takes is for one illegal backroom deal to go 
unnoticed or a legislator with a stake in a particular stock and we're all 
fucked by some monopoly. We could do without the first two sentences.

At least that would make the undesirable illegal without any more harm to 
the economy, not that it would actually stop money in politics.

or company that runs those living areas pays less money for a bulk deal.

Never take the ISP side on something like this. Did I mention they lied? 

These data caps and the prices associated with them are on a region basis.

California where in theory Time Warner and ATT can compete. Having any sort 
of data cap for a home network is unacceptable.
comments.author: EdwardERS

comments.text:
+EdwardERS 500 GB of data is a fuck ton man, more than you should need in a 
month.
comments.author: mrvipersniper

comments.text:
Fucking data caps. Go over 500 GB and pay another $10 for every 10 GB. AT&T 
never tells you about that, but across all of their regions and services it 
exists. I remember a salesman soliciting door to door with so many empty 
promises and bald faced lies, you'd think they were Mormons. 

"Oh, you don't need internet faster than 24 Mb." - AT&T Salesman 
"Oh, that 500 GB is just for your email." - U-Verse Worker.

I bet, wouldn't want me to crash that 500 GB data cap too fast during a 
Steam Sale. All these ISPs have the intention of drowning Netflix, Youtube 
and Steam along with Piracy in the bathtub. At this rate I don't see how 
Blu Ray quality bitrates are gonna be a thing for streaming for another 
decade, but by then we're all gonna have 4K tvs.

top_comment.author: readyfor2016 now

comments.text:
+Jpkrao you do know that if internet becomes regulated as a utility you 
will be paying MORE for the same data you use now right? That's what Net 
Neutrality actually is. Allow all content to come through without any 
compression by the service provider and regulate it as a utility. To me 
that sounds like A. no more paying for speed, now paying per byte. B. No 
more compressing high bandwidth content hence making my digital consumption 
take up more bytes. C. No more package deals as it's no longer an all you 
can eat buffet of data. And D (this is the kicker) Content coming directly 
from the ISP will flow just as content from anyone else (cloud DVR 
recordings yeah that'll count against your data usage) That's lose for the 
content providers (youtube, Netflix, hulu etc), lose for the service 
providers (Comcast, Verizon, Google etc) and lose for the consumer (you, 
me, etc). But it's a BIG WIN for the government who can say they did what 
the people asked for.
comments.author: Chris Drushler

comments.text:
+Jpkrao
didn't know that, thanks.

comments.text:

money to them every month, if you use more bandwidth than what you are 
allowed to. Those ISPs are crooks.
